questions.text:
This survey tool takes only a few minutes to use. Its purpose is to help you apply former skills as well as new awareness to your current or upcoming written work.

[Survey Type: 1]

Please read the consent form below and choose to consent or not to consent to include your survey responses as anonymous data in a research study.  Whether or not you consent, your tasks are the same, you will receive credit, and your teacher will never know your decision.  If you select “Yes,” it means you have read or have had read to you the consent form below, and you agree to include your responses as anonymous study data.
choices: Click here to affirm that you have read (or had read to you) the consent form above.

questions.text: Please provide the following information, which will only be used (anonymously) if you are part of the research study. Your Major(s)/Minor(s):
In what year were you born?
How many total years of college have you had (at SBU and anywhere else, combined)?
Did you take the course WRT 102 - Intermediate Writing Workshop at Stony Brook University?

question.text: When did you take the course WRT 102 - Intermediate Writing Workshop at Stony Brook University?

What, if any, specific knowledge and/or skills about writing did you develop in WRT 102?  List as many answers as you can recall.  If you cannot recall any, then write "I don't remember."  If none, write "None."
Have you taken any courses in which you primarily developed knowledge or skills in writing?
When did you take that course?
Where did you take that course, and what was its name and/or course number (e.g., AP English Language and Composition, WRT 101)?  If you don't remember, please write "I don't remember."
What specific knowledge and/or skills about writing did you learn in that course?  List as many answers as you can recall.  If you cannot recall any, write "I don't remember."  If none, write "None."

questions.text: <mark>Curiosity</mark> involves the desire to know more about the world.  Regarding your academic writing, how curious do you think you are?

<mark>Responsibility</mark> involves the ability to take ownership of one’s actions and understand the consequences of those actions for oneself and others.  Regarding your academic writing, how responsible do you think you are?
<mark>Flexibility</mark> involves the ability to adapt to situations, expectations, or demands.  Regarding your academic writing, how flexible do you think you are?
<mark>Engagement</mark> involves a sense of investment and involvement in learning.  Regarding your academic writing, how engaged do you think you are?
<mark>Openness</mark> involves the willingness to consider new ways of being and thinking in the world.  Regarding your academic writing, how open do you think you are?
<mark>Creativity</mark> involves the ability to use new approaches to generate, investigate, and represent ideas.  Regarding your academic writing, how creative do you think you are?
<mark>Persistence</mark> involves the ability to sustain interest in and attention to short- and long-term projects.  Regarding your academic writing, how persistent do you think you are?

<mark>Metacognition</mark> involves the ability to reflect on one’s own thinking as well as on the individual and cultural processes used to structure knowledge.  Regarding your academic writing, how metacognitive do you think you are?
